block.p: Intelligence Chief is Shift To Deputy State Dept. Post John D. Negroponte, whom President Bush installed less than two years ago as the first director of national intelligence, will leave his post to become the State Department's second-ranking official, Bush administration officials said.

Iraq Defends Hussein Hanging The Iraqi prime minister's office mounted its first public defense of the way the government carried out the execution of Saddam Hussein and said Iraqi authorities had detained a guard they believe recorded the execution on a cellphone camera.

The White House declined to criticize the conduct of the execution, even as State Department officials and military leaders in Baghdad raised questions about the timing of the hanging and the manner of the execution.

Some key Senate Democrats say they could consider supporting a short-term increase in American troop levels in Iraq, a stance that reflects division within the party and could provide an opening for President Bush as he prepares to announce his new plan for Iraq.

Kenya Closes Somali Border Kenyan officials said they were closing their northern border because of the conflict in Somalia, but denied accusations from United Nations officials that they had turned back hundreds of refugees.

Ch치vez Unifies Socialist Party President Hugo Ch치vez of Venezuela has begun forging a single Socialist party among his varied supporters, one of his recent efforts to create momentum for far-reaching changes to the political system.

Lab Barred from Approving New Voting Machines A laboratory that has tested most of the nation's electronic voting systems has been temporarily barred from approving new machines after federal officials found that it was not following procedures and could not document that it was conducting all the required tests.

Trial Relies on Wiretapping The government will rely largely on wiretapped conversations when it puts Jose Padilla and two others on trial as a ''North American support cell'' that sent money, goods and recruits abroad to assist ''global jihad.''

Severing Ties With Lobbyists On the precipice of regaining power after 12 years, House Democrats said they would move immediately to try to sever ties between lawmakers and lobbyists who figured into scandals that helped Democrats win control of Congress.

Former President Is Buried Gerald R. Ford was buried on a grassy hill beside the rushing waters of the Grand River in Michigan as the sun set, a final farewell in a week of remembrances for the nation's 38th president.

Drugs Said to Harm Heart Two drugs, pergolide and cabergoline, used to treat Parkinson's disease and other disorders, can seriously damage heart valves, researchers are reporting in The New England Journal of Medicine.

With a Sweeping Agenda, Spitzer Challenges Albany Gov. Eliot Spitzer, in his first address to the New York Legislature, proposed overhauling almost every corner of the state's operations and policies, saying he would move swiftly to guarantee health insurance for all children in the state, cut property taxes by $6 billion and broadly overhaul ethics and lobbying rules. A1
Zoning Laws Slow Growth The 20-year building boom on Staten Island, long New York City's fastest-growing borough, is decelerating dramatically, thanks to new zoning rules. B1

Brought to You by The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to announce today a deal with Geico, the auto insurance giant, to place an advertisement atop the George Washington Bridge toll plaza in Fort Lee, N.J. B1

Home Depot Fires Its Chief In a surprising turnaround, Home Depot's board decided Robert L. Nardelli, the chief executive, should go, and it gave him a $210 million exit package. What ultimately divided the board and its chief executive appeared to have been Mr. Nardelli's compensation.

Eli Lilly's Troubled Drug Eli Lilly found that compared with an older antipsychotic drug, Haldol, patients taking Zyprexa, a drug that treats schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, would be more likely to develop heart disease.
Editorials: The ugly death of Saddam Hussein; new Congress, leftover challenge; out with the old; a big hero in the big city.
